case_name: Nishi Kanta Mondal v. State of West Bengal

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 7 of 1972 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 7 of 1972. Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ In the, nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Petition filed by Nishi Kanta Mondal through jail for habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: K. Puri, for the petitioner. N. Mukherjee and G. S. Chatterjee, for the respondent The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Khanna, J.-This is a petition through jail for the issuance of a writ of habeas companypus by Nishi Kanta Mondal

facts.text: Nishi Kanta Mondal ordered to be detained by District Magistrate, 24-Parganas under section 3 of the West Bengal Prevention of Violent Activities Act, 1970 (President's Act No. 19 of 1970).

anchor.surface_text: who has been ordered by the District Magistrate, 24-Parganas to be detained under section 3 of the West Bengal  Prevention of Violent Activities  Act, 1970  Presidents Act No. 19 of 1970 , hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Detention order No. 352/71 dated 6-7-71 issued by District Magistrate 24-Parganas directing detention of Nishi Kanta Mondal son of Radhanath Mondal of Daccapara, P.S. Bongaon, Dt. 24-Parganas.

anchor.surface_text: The order of detention reads as under GOVERNMENT OF WEST BENGAL OFFICE OF THE DISTRICT MAGISTRATE 24-PARGANAS ORDER No. 352/71 Dated, the 6-7-71 Whereas I am satisfied with respect to the person known as Shri Nishi Kanta Mondal, son of Shri Radhanath Mondal of Daccapara, P. S. Bongaon, Dt. 24-Parganas

facts.text: Petitioner Nishi Kanta Mondal arrested on July 8, 1971 and served with detention order and grounds of detention on the same day.

anchor.surface_text: Given under my hand and seal of office. Sd - DISTRICT MAGISTRATE 24-PARGANAS 6-7-71 In pursuance of the above order, the petitioner was arrested on July 8, 1971 and was served with the order as well as the grounds of detention on the same day.

facts.text: District Magistrate sent report to State Government on July 10, 1971 about detention order along with grounds and particulars.

anchor.surface_text: On July 10, 1971 the District Magistrate sent report to the State Government about his having passed the order for the detention of the petitioner. The grounds of detention and other necessary particulars were also sent along with the report.

facts.text: State Government approved detention order on July 17, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government, after companysidering the report and other particulars, approved the detention order on July 17, 1971.

facts.text: Petitioner's representation received by State Government on July 30, 1971 and rejected on August 5, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Representation made by the petitioner against his detention was received by the State Government on July 30, 1971. The representation was companysidered by the State Government and rejected on August 5, 1971.

facts.text: Petitioner's case placed before Advisory Board on August 6, 1971 with representation.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the petitioner was placed before the Advisory Board on August 6, 1971. The petitioners representation was also sent to the Advisory Board.

facts.text: Advisory Board gave petitioner personal hearing, considered materials and representation, submitted report on September 14, 1971 opining sufficient cause for detention.

anchor.surface_text: The Advisory Board, after companysidering the material placed before it as well as the representation sent by the petitioner and after giving him a hearing in person, submitted its report to the State Government on September 14, 1971. Opinion was expressed by the Advisory Board that there was sufficient cause for the detention of the petitioner.

facts.text: State Government confirmed detention order on October 5, 1971 and communicated to petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government passed an order on October 5, 1971 companyfirming the order for the ,detention of the petitioner. The companyfirmation order was there,after companymunicated to the petitioner.

facts.text: Affidavit filed by Shri Chandi Charan Bose, Deputy Secretary, Home Special Department, Government of West Bengal in opposition.

anchor.surface_text: The petition has, been resisted by the State of West Bengal and the affidavit of Shri Chandi Charan Bose, Deputy Secretary, Home  Special  Department, Government of West Bengal has been filed in opposition to the petition.

facts.text: On 12-2-71 at about 02.00 hrs., Nishi Kanta Mondal and associates armed with bombs and lethal weapons attacked Shri K. K. Naskar, I.A.S., S.D.O., Bongaon and his guard by hurling bombs, injuring the guard constable near quarters of Shri S. C. Sarkar, Magistrate 1st Class, Bongaon at Amlapara near Bongaon Court, creating panic and disturbing public order.

anchor.surface_text: On 12-2-71 at about 02.00 hrs., you and some of your associates being armed with bombs and other lethal weapons attacked Shri K. K. Naskar, I.A.S., S.D.O., Bongaon and his guard by hurling bombs and thereby causing injuries to the guard companystable when they came out on hearing sounds of explosion of bombs near the quarters of Shri S. C. Sarkar, Magistrate 1st Class, Bongaon, at Amlapara near Bongaon Court.

facts.text: On 23-2-71 between 10.45 hrs. and 02.15 hrs Bongaon Police searched a house at Subhaspalli, Bongaon and recovered 3 high explosive bombs and some explosive materials from possession of Nishi Kanta Mondal and associates.

anchor.surface_text: On 23-2-71 between 10.45 hrs. and 02.15 hrs Bongaon Police on receipt of a secret information searched a house at Subhaspalli, Bongaon and recovered 3 high explosive bombs and some explosive materials from you and your associates possession.

facts.text: West Bengal Prevention of Violent Activities Act, 1970 is President's Act No. 19 of 1970 enacted under powers conferred by section 3 of West Bengal State Legislature Delegation of Powers Act, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The first companytention which has been advanced by Mr. Puri is that the Act was enacted by the President in exercise of the powers companyferred by, section 3 of the West Bengal State Legislature  Delegation of Powers  Act, 1970.

facts.text: Proclamation issued on 19th March 1970 under Article 356 by President, published G.S.R. 490.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 of the aforesaid Act defined Proclamation to mean the Proclamation issued on the 19th day of March, 1970, under article 356 of the Constitution by the President, and published with the numberification of the Government of India it  the Ministry of Home Affairs No. G.S.R. 490 of the said date,

facts.text: The Proclamation dated March 19, 1970 was revoked by another Proclamation by the President in the beginning of this month.

anchor.surface_text: It is urged by Mr. Puri that the above mentioned Proclamation was revoked by the President by another Proclamation in the beginning of this month.

facts.text: Petitioner contends that due to revocation of Proclamation, President's Act No. 19 of 1970 ceased to have effect.

anchor.surface_text: On account of the revocation of the Proclamation, the Presidents Act No. 19 of 1970, according to the learned companynsel, ceased to have effect. As such, the petitioner companyld number be kept in detention in pursuance of the order made under that Act.

facts.text: Court holds that Act No. 19 of 1970 continues in force despite revocation of Proclamation, per Article 357(2), for one year after unless repealed.

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our opinion, numberforce in the above companytention because it is based upon the assumption that the law made by the President ceases to operate immediately upon the revocation of the Proclamation. This assumption is number companyrect and runs companytrary to clause  2  of article 357 of the Constitution.

facts.text: One year period after Proclamation cessation has not expired and Act not repealed or re-enacted.

anchor.surface_text: As the aforesaid period of one year has number expired and as the provisions of the Act have number been repealed or re-enacted with or without modification by Act of the appropriate Legislature, the impugned Act should be held to be still in force.

facts.text: Petitioner contends detention order not in conformity with section 10 as it did not specify date of detention.

anchor.surface_text: Argument has then been advanced by Mr. Puri that the im- pugned detention order was number in companyformity with section 10 of the Act as it did number specify the date of detention.

facts.text: Court rejects contention that section 10 requires specifying date of detention in order; detention commences on custody.

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves unable to accede to this submission. All that section 10 companytemplates is that the State Government should within 30 days from the companymencement of the detention place before the Advisory Board the grounds on which the order has been made

facts.text: Petitioner contends grounds of detention not germane to objects of Act.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it has been argued by Mr. Puri that the grounds of detention are number germane to the objects for which a person can be ordered to be detained under the Act.

facts.text: Court finds grounds germane as incidents involve offences under Explosive Substances Act, 1908 disturbing public order per section 3(2)(d).

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest from the above definition that the expression acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order would include the companymission of an offence under the Explosive Substances Act, 1908 when the companymission of such offence disturbs or is likely to disturb public order.

facts.text: Petition dismissed as detention in accordance with law.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, find numberinfirmity in the impugned detention order. It also cannot be said that the detention of the petitioner is number in accordance with law. The petition companysequently fails and is dismissed.
Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ In the, nature of habeas companypus.

issues.text: Whether the President's Act No. 19 of 1970 ceases to have effect upon the revocation of the Proclamation under Article 356 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: It is urged by Mr. Puri that the above mentioned Proclamation was revoked by the President by another Proclamation in the beginning of this month. On account of the revocation of the Proclamation, the Presidents Act No. 19 of 1970, according to the learned counsel, ceased to have effect. As such, the petitioner could not be kept in detention in pursuance of the order made under that Act.

issues.text: Whether the impugned detention order was not in conformity with section 10 of the Act as it did not specify the date of detention?

anchor.surface_text: Argument has then been advanced by Mr. Puri that the im- pugned detention order was not in conformity with section 10 of the Act as it did not specify the date of detention. Section 10 reads as under In every case where a detention order has been made under this Act, the State Government shall, within thirty days from the date of detention under the order, place before the Advisory Board, constituted by it under section 9, the

issues.text: Whether the grounds of detention are germane to the objects for which a person can be ordered to be detained under the Act?

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it has been argued by Mr. Puri that the grounds of detention are not germane to the objects for which a person can be ordered to be detained under the Act. In this connection, we find that, according to the grounds of detention which were furnished to the petitioner, he was being detained as he was acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance

arguments.claim: President's Act No. 19 of 1970 ceased to have effect upon revocation of the Proclamation, rendering the detention invalid

On account of the revocation of the Proclamation, the Presidents Act No. 19 of 1970, according to the learned counsel, ceased to have effect. As such, the petitioner could not be kept in detention in pursuance of the order made under that Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Grounds show petitioner acted prejudicially to public order per section 3(2)(d): bomb attack on SDO created panic/disturbed order (offence under Explosive Substances Act); recovery of bombs shows propensity to disturb order despite non-use due to police intervention; object of detention is preventive

arguments.claim: Act No. 19 of 1970 continues in force despite revocation of Proclamation per Article 357(2)

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our opinion, noforce in the above contention because it is based upon the assumption that the law made by the President ceases to operate immediately upon the revocation of the Proclamation. This assumption is no correct and runs contrary to clause 2 of article 357 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Section 10 does not require detention order to specify date of detention; compliance achieved by placing grounds before Advisory Board within 30 days of actual commencement

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves unable to accede to this submission. All that section 10 contemplates is that the State Government should within 30 days from the commencement of the detention place before the Advisory Board the grounds on which the order has been made

arguments.claim: Grounds of detention are germane as they fall within section 3(2)(d): offences under Explosive Substances Act disturbing/likely to disturb public order, showing propensity for preventive detention

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, we find that, according to the grounds of detention which were furnished to the petitioner, he was being detained as he was acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order as evidenced by particulars given below On 12-2-71 at about 02.00 hrs., you and some of your associates

holdings.text: President's Act No. 19 of 1970 does not cease to have effect upon revocation of the Proclamation and continues in force per Article 357(2) as the one-year period has not expired and the Act has not been repealed or re-enacted.

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our opinion, numberforce in the above companytention because it is based upon the assumption that the law made by the President ceases to operate immediately upon the revocation of the Proclamation. This assumption is number companyrect and runs companytrary to clause  2  of article 357 of the Constitution. According to that clause, any law made in exercise of the power of the Legislature of the State by Parliament or the President or other authority referred to in sub-clause  a  of clause  1  which Parliament or the President or such other authority would number, but for the issue of a Proclamation under article 356, have been company- petent to make shall, to the extent of the incompetency, cease to have effect on the expiration of a period of one year after the Proclamation has ceased to operate

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's assumption that law ceases immediately on revocation is incorrect; Article 357(2) explicitly provides for continuance for one year post-Proclamation unless repealed or re-enacted by legislature; factual check confirms period not expired and no repeal.

holdings.text: Detention order is in conformity with section 10 of the Act; it is not required to specify the date of detention as section 10 mandates placing grounds before Advisory Board within 30 days from commencement of detention, which occurs upon custody.

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves unable to accede to this submission. All that section 10 companytemplates is that the State Government should within 30 days from the companymencement of the detention place before the Advisory Board the grounds on which the order has been made and the representation, if any, made by the person affected by the order, and in case where an order has been made by an officer specified in sub- section  3  of section 3, also the report made by such officer under sub-section  4  of section 3. There is numberhing, however, in the section which makes it obligatory on the part of the detaining authority to specify the date of the companymencement of detention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of section 10 requires action within 30 days from actual commencement (custody); pre-specifying date impractical as apprehension date uncertain; would undermine enforceability if delayed; phrase refers to actual start date.

holdings.text: Grounds of detention are germane to the objects of the Act under section 3(2)(d) as incidents involve commission of offences under Explosive Substances Act disturbing or likely to disturb public order, indicating propensity for preventive detention.

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection, we find that, according to the grounds of detention which were furnished to the petitioner, he was being detained as he was acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order as evidenced by particulars given below On 12-2-71 at about 02.00 hrs., you and some of your associates being armed with bombs and other lethal weapons attacked Shri K. K. Naskar, I.A.S., S.D.O., Bongaon and his guard by hurling bombs and thereby causing injuries to the guard companystable when they came out on hearing sounds of explosion of bombs near the quarters of Shri S. C. Sarkar, Magistrate 1st Class, Bongaon, at Amlapara near Bongaon Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grounds detail bomb attack creating panic (disturbed order) and bomb possession (likely to disturb, propensity shown by prior incident); falls squarely within s3(2)(d) definition; preventive object satisfied even if police intervention prevents actual disturbance.

holdings.text: No infirmity in the detention order and detention of the petitioner is in accordance with law; petition fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, find numberinfirmity in the impugned detention order. It also cannot be said that the detention of the petitioner is number in accordance with law. The petition companysequently fails and is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All contentions rejected; procedures followed, grounds valid, Act operative; cumulative application upholds detention.

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our opinion, numberforce in the above companytention because it is based upon the assumption that the law made by the President ceases to operate immediately upon the revocation of the Proclamation. This assumption is number companyrect and runs companytrary to clause  2  of article 357 of the Constitution. According to that clause, any law made in exercise of the power of the Legislature of the State by Parliament or the President or other authority referred to in sub-clause  a  of clause  1  which Parliament or the President or such other authority would number, but for the issue of a Proclamation under article 356, have been company- petent to make shall, to the extent of the incompetency, cease to have effect on the expiration of a period of one year after the Proclamation has ceased to operate

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves unable to accede to this submission. All that section 10 companytemplates is that the State Government should within 30 days from the companymencement of the detention place before the Advisory Board the grounds on which the order has been made and the representation, if any, made by the person affected by the order, and in case where an order has been made by an officer specified in sub- section  3  of section 3, also the report made by such officer under sub-section  4  of section 3. There is numberhing, however, in the section which makes it obligatory on the part of the detaining authority to specify the date of the companymencement of detention.
The petition companysequently fails and is dismissed.
